executive_summary: The 61st parliamentary meeting on March 11, 2025, highlighted tensions within the VVD-led coalition as it navigated contentious debates on housing enforcement, EU policy, and climate funding. The PVV's assertive presence and populist motions tested coalition unity, while opposition parties like GroenLinks-PvdA capitalized on housing and welfare issues to rally support. The meeting revealed shifting alliances, with NSC occasionally breaking ranks and right-wing parties leveraging cost-of-living concerns to block progressive climate measures.

main_topics.summary: Debate centered on fines for landlords violating rental laws, with opposition criticizing the coalition's slow enforcement. Minister Keijzer (VVD) downplayed violations, emphasizing municipal autonomy.

party_positions.VVD (Keijzer): Defended gradual enforcement, framing it as a local governance issue to avoid centralization backlash.
party_positions.GroenLinks-PvdA (De Hoop): Pushed for transparency and stricter enforcement to appeal to renters and highlight coalition failures.
party_positions.PVV: Focused on immigration-linked housing shortages, diverting attention from landlord accountability.

main_topics.outcome: No immediate decision, but pressure mounted for future enforcement metrics.
main_topics.political_context: Housing remains a wedge issue, with opposition exploiting coalition delays to rally voter support.

main_topics.summary: PVV/FVD pushed isolationist motions, straining the coalition's pro-EU stance. GroenLinks-PvdA positioned itself as the EU's defender.

party_positions.PVV/FVD: Rallied nationalist base with anti-EU rhetoric, testing NSC/CDA's tolerance.
party_positions.GroenLinks-PvdA: Framed EU solidarity as essential for centrist appeal, isolating PVV.
party_positions.VVD/NSC: Balanced coalition unity with pro-EU pragmatism, avoiding outright confrontation.

main_topics.outcome: Motion-Eerdmans (anti-EU) rejected, but PVV gained symbolic traction.
main_topics.political_context: EU policy remains a fault line, with populists exploiting euroscepticism ahead of potential reshuffles.

main_topics.summary: Right-wing parties weaponized economic concerns to block green transition measures, passing a motion defunding the Climate Citizens' Assembly.

party_positions.VVD/JA21/PVV: Prioritized short-term economic relief over climate goals to retain working-class voters.
party_positions.GroenLinks-PvdA: Framed climate inaction as elitist, but failed to sway centrists.
party_positions.NSC: Broke ranks on some motions, signaling coalition fragility.

main_topics.outcome: Motion-Eerdmans passed, undermining progressive climate efforts.
main_topics.political_context: Energy policy is a wedge issue, with right-wing parties linking it to inflation to erode green support.

key_decisions: Motion-Eerdmans to defund Climate Citizens' Assembly passed (VVD/JA21/PVV support)—right-wing leverage in coalition.
Motion-Kröger/Erkens on Smart Readiness Indicators passed unanimously except JA21—technical consensus amid ideological divides.
Motion-Klaver (benefit linkage) rejected despite NSC support—coalition discipline fraying.
Motion-Ergin (price controls) failed—highlighting resistance to market intervention.
political_dynamics: Coalition stability was tested by PVV/FVD's populist motions, with NSC occasionally siding with the left. VVD and GroenLinks-PvdA engaged in rare tactical alignments on housing enforcement. Opposition parties (SP, DENK) used welfare debates to solidify minority/low-income bases, while PVV/BBB exploited cost-of-living concerns to peel off working-class voters.
meeting_tone: Contentious and procedural, with dramatic exchanges on EU policy and housing. PVV's dominance in chair roles (Bosma) added to the adversarial atmosphere.
strategic_implications: The meeting revealed: 1) NSC's willingness to break ranks, signaling potential coalition realignments; 2) PVV's success in framing climate policies as elitist; 3) Opposition's focus on housing enforcement as a vulnerability for the VVD-led coalition.
next_steps: Coalition parties (VVD, NSC, CDA) will likely negotiate behind the scenes to prevent further fractures.
Opposition parties (GroenLinks-PvdA, SP) may escalate housing enforcement critiques ahead of local elections.
PVV/FVD expected to intensify anti-EU rhetoric, pressuring NSC/CDA to take clearer stances.
